JUDGES: Giovanni Bonello;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in FAC . He was represented before the ORG by Mr J. Brydak , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr J. PERSON of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the prosecution filed a bill of indictment against the applicant with ORG . He was charged with several financial offences .

The case was heard by the panel composed of Judge PERSON and CARDINAL lay judges . A hearing scheduled for DATE was cancelled due to the illness of CARDINAL of the lay judges . On DATE the lay judge died . In addition , Judge PERSON was due to leave ORG to take up a post at ORG on DATE .
As a result the applicant ’s case had to be heard de novo by a newly composed panel .
On DATE the Minister of ORG seconded Judge PERSON from ORG to serve as a judge of ORG from DATE to CARDINAL DATE .

On DATE Judge PERSON was put on a list of judges of ORG of ORG . On DATE the President of ORG assigned Judge PERSON to the applicant ’s case under LAW . He noted that the judge who had been previously assigned to the case was due to take up a different judicial post . Furthermore , it was necessary to divide work evenly between judges in the division .
On DATE Judge PERSON scheduled the first hearing in the applicant ’s case for DATE . It appears that subsequently Judge PERSON was appointed a regional court judge .
On DATE ORG , composed of Judge PERSON and CARDINAL lay judges , convicted the applicant of fraud . It sentenced him to DATE imprisonment and a fine . The applicant appealed .
On DATE ORG upheld the first - instance judgment .

The applicant lodged a cassation appeal , arguing that the panel of ORG had been composed in breach of LAW . He submitted that the President of ORG should have assigned his case to the next judge on the list of judges and not to Judge PERSON Since that was not the case , the composition of the court was decided in an administrative manner . The applicant further relied on LAW , arguing the lack of objective impartiality of ORG .
On DATE ORG requested the President of the CARDINALrd Criminal Section of the Wrocław ORG to provide a list of judges , referred to in LAW , which had been valid on DATE .

On DATE the requested list of judges together with an explanation as to the composition of the panel was received by ORG . The list of judges adjudicating in ORG of ORG valid on DATE included Judge PERSON The list contained CARDINAL judges listed in numerical order . Judge PERSON was fifth on the list and Judge PERSON was eleventh on the list . He was indicated as having been seconded to ORG by a decision of the Minister of ORG of CARDINAL DATE . It was further stated that on DATE the applicant ’s case was assigned to Judge PERSON The reasons for this decision were even distribution of work between judges in the division and the necessity to provide Judge PERSON , a newly - seconded judge , with cases to examine . ORG was further informed that PERSON , the judge previously assigned to the case , had been due to be transferred to ORG on DATE .

On DATE ORG held a hearing . It dismissed the applicant ’s cassation appeal as manifestly ill - founded and pronounced the most relevant reasons for its decision . ORG further informed the parties that due to the manifestly ill - founded character of the cassation appeal , it was not required to provide written grounds for its decision ( LAW ) .
Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure ( , , ORG ” ) stated at the material time as follows :

“ A judge ( ... ) is assigned [ to a case ] in the order in which the case was filed and by reference to a list of judges of a given court or division which is accessible to the parties . A departure from this rule is permissible only by way of omitting a judge on the ground of his / her illness or on other important grounds and [ that circumstance ] should be specified in a decision on holding a hearing ”

Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the ORG provides that in cases concerning the most serious charges the composition of a panel is decided DATE on request of a prosecutor or a defence counsel – by drawing lots .

In a decision of DATE ( case no . V KK CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) ORG held that the notion of “ other important grounds ” within the meaning of this provision comprised “ a heavy workload of a judge which made it impossible for him / her to decide on a case before the expiry of a limitation period ” . ORG noted that the rule established in LAW ORG was not absolute and could be subject to limitations which took account of practical necessities .

In a resolution of CARDINAL DATE ( case no . I ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) ORG found that LAW ORG would be breached if a different judge than the judge next on the list of judges was assigned to hear a case and if no important ground had been invoked to justify the departure from the rule .

The Ordinance of the Minister of Justice of CARDINAL DATE on particular rules concerning assignment and drawing of judicial panels came into force on DATE . Paragraph CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW required that in each division there had to be a list of judges in alphabetical order . In addition , the list should include annotations about any circumstances constituting grounds for departure from the rules of assignment of judges specified in LAW ORG .
